last_post.content:
This report, Terrorist Use of End-to-End Encryption: Insights from a Year of Multi-Stakeholder Discussion, centres upon this very important fact:

"Encryption experts, digital rights advocates, and service providers agree that the systematic surveillance of encrypted content _is technically unfeasible_ unless the security and privacy of all users is to be compromised."

https://www.techagainstterrorism.org/2023/01/11/terrorist-use-of-end-to-end-encryption-insights-from-a-year-of-multi-stakeholder-discussion/

title: Access is not the same as accessibility: A framework for making research papers truly open – arXiv.org blog

last_post.content:
Very glad to see the #arxiv steps toward #accessibility (#a11y). These include "offering well-formatted #HTML, alongside #PDF and #TeX source."
https://blog.arxiv.org/2023/01/19/access-is-not-the-same-as-accessibility-a-framework-for-making-research-papers-truly-open/

PS: There are 𝘮𝘢𝘯𝘺 reasons to offer well-formatted HTML alongside PDF, or to stop publishing PDF-only. Accessibility is first, followed closely by making work friendly to mobile users, users with low bandwidth, and users who need to text-mine, cut/paste, or use machine translation.

There's a good discussion of packing regular tetrahedra here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedron_packing

and here:

Jeffrey Lagarias and Chuanming Zong, Mysteries in packing regular tetrahedra
http://www.ams.org/notices/201211/rtx121101540p.pdf

The proof that equal-sized regular tetrahedra can't fill 3d space boils down to thinking about the picture here, where θ is a bit more than 7°. But I'd hate to have to formalize it in a completely rigorous way, on a computer. (Some other people would enjoy that challenge.)

(2/n)

Aristotle claimed that identical regular tetrahedra could be packed in a way that fills space. It seems unlikely if you actually try it - but only in 1925 was it proved impossible. And only in 2010 did people prove a nontrivial upper bound on the density of the packing you can achieve, namely

0.9999999999999999999999974

On the other hand, the densest known packing has density about .8563 - there's a discussion and picture on Wolfram's website:

https://blog.wolfram.com/2010/08/30/tetrahedra-packing/

(1/n)

This is a really good paper:

https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2212.03551/

Gets at a thing that has long worried me: Experts in the field can use conversational shorthand like "believe" and "know" with little risk. Outsiders hear those terms and naturally anthropomorphize.

LLMs are powerful and useful, but require human oversight. Just because GPT-3 says it doesn't make it so. We need to explain in ways that highlights risk to ordinary folks.

Came my way via @simon.

title: Topological Phases in a PT-Symmetric Dissipative Kitaev Chain

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08446 by Kawasaki & Obuse. Authors study the topological phase in the dissipative Kitaev chain via a Markovian quantum master equation. Lindbladians are classified in terms of non-Hermitian topological phases. Lindbladian retains PT symmetry. #CondMat #MesHall #arXiv_2301_08446

title: Tell Us About Your Experience With the Liver Transplant System

last_post.content:
Every year, thousands of Americans facing liver failure try to get new organs. Many of these are successful. But some experiences with the liver transplant process go wrong. The chances of success often depend on which hospital replaces your liver.

For an upcoming @ProPublica story, I'm looking to speak with medical providers, experts, regulators, and patients who have experience with our liver transplant system. If you're one of these people, please fill out this form. https://www.propublica.org/getinvolved/tell-us-about-your-experience-with-the-liver-transplant-system

L'avenir de la recherche d'information n'est pas dans les grands modèles de langage qui ont réponse à tout car trouver de l'information nécessite que celle-ci soit située pour répondre à la diversité des contextes d'usages : https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3498366.3505816 "Nous devrions chercher à créer des outils qui aident les utilisateurs à trouver et à donner un sens aux informations plutôt que des outils qui prétendent tout faire pour eux." @emilymbender et Chirag Shah

I remember when Netscape announced that it was going to release the source code for its web browser. I'd been working in open source for decades, but this was the first major corporate contribution of previously-closed code to the community. It was huge. (I had, not long before, tried to get my employer Informix to open source the Illustra DBMS, but failed).

Jamie Zawinski was right in the middle of it all. He just posted this history on his blog. Fun reading!

https://www.jwz.org/blog/2023/01/mozilla-orgs-25th-anniversary/

title: Publishers lament the removal of Twitter Moments as referral traffic dips

last_post.content:
News publishers are bemoaning the drop in Twitter traffic referrals under Musk. But they have a plan: They'll put more of their stuff on Facebook and LinkedIn.

Because they're monumentally oblivious to the lesson they've (again) failed to learn. Namely: Do not trust or rely on centralized systems you don't control.

https://digiday.com/media/publishers-lament-the-removal-of-twitter-moments-as-referral-traffic-dips/

title: Inside the Moonshot Effort to Finally Figure Out the Brain

last_post.content:
The MICrONS program was a hugely ambitious effort to map the connectivity patterns of 1 mm3 of mouse cortex and their relationships to brain function. I know that it led to some tremendous technical advances in automated electron microscopy and processing of that data. It also led to a connectivity map for 200K neurons and 500 million synapses.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2017/10/12/148291/inside-the-moonshot-effort-to-finally-figure-out-the-brain/

What I understand less about is whether the new concepts and findings that emerged from the project.
@neurobongo, @xaq, (anyone): What is the status there? (Note this Q is not a criticism - if it's all still tech and maps thus far, that's still a really important step).

Very thoughtful analysis of #receptiogate by David Rundle: "#Receptiogate and gate-keeping", https://bonaelitterae.wordpress.com/2023/01/23/receptiogate-and-gate-keeping/. Among several good points, this final one: "...asserting status is not a route to acceptance as a scholar; on the contrary, it is symptomatic of the unscholarly". And another one from earlier in the piece: "...realising that Receptio’s fabrication is a parody of a system of higher education which is itself beyond parody."

title: "Block direct messages from people you don't follow" is a mute, not a block · Issue #11882 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
I've had DMs blocked on Mastodon for a while (same as on twitter), but I just learned that on Mastodon, "block DMs" actually means "mute DMs" https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/11882

so the sender has no way to tell that the receiver has DMs blocked

title: Rationing Medicine Through Bureaucracy: Authorization Restrictions in Medicare

last_post.content:
I just love economics. Here's a new NBER working paper (authors are Harvard & UChicago) with a whole lot of jargon and fancy-looking math to justify a model which assumes (a) patients can quantitatively evaluate the relative health benefits of one medicine to another; and (b) patients have infinite budgets and so the only factor in choosing a medicine is its relative benefit.

https://www.nber.org/papers/w30878

title: ChatGPT is now writing legislation. Is this the future?

last_post.content:
#ChatGPT is now writing legislation¹ — An Act drafted with the help of ChatGPT to regulate generative artificial intelligence models like ChatGPT — introduced by Massachusetts state Senator Barry Finegold, features an interesting disclaimer, "This act has been drafted with the help of ChatGPT and any errors or inaccuracies in the bill should not be attributed to the language model but rather to its human authors."²

¹ https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/01/23/chatgpt-is-now-writing-legislation-is-this-future/

title: Multimillion-dollar trade in paper authorships alarms publishers

last_post.content:
As long as scientific careers are evaluated by 'published number of papers', things like this will happen. You can play whac-a-mole forever or you can stop using pointless metrics.

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00062-9

There's more money and prestige in playing whac-a-mole.... it's the same thinking problem with ChatGPT in university assessments, isn't it? You could a) replace the system or b) throw money at it. Everybody chooses b).

Good morning! Here's your Monday ice update - enjoy your week!

#Arctic sea ice extent is currently the 4th lowest on record (JAXA data).

• about 150,000 km² below the 2010s mean
• about 730,000 km² below the 2000s mean
• about 1,280,000 km² below the 1990s mean
• about 1,750,000 km² below the 1980s mean

Other real-time plots: https://zacklabe.com/arctic-sea-ice-extentconcentration/

This is fascinating! The Braille Institute has developed a font - free to download - that's designed to be clearer for readers with lower vision.

An example of one of the aspects of low legibility that they tackled attached.

It's named Atkinson Hyperlegible. Atkinson was the Institute's founder - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Robert_Atkinson

Here's where you can read about the font and download it: https://brailleinstitute.org/freefont

#Accessibility

Via @tombofnull

title: Palantir and Posit Partner to Integrate RStudio into Palantir Foundry

last_post.content:
Wow. RStudio (recently rebranded as Posit) is partnering with Palantir. Yes, the same Palantir with ties to Cambridge Analytica. The same Palantir that partners with and actively supports ICE and other oppressive surveillance.

This is really not ok ethically, and can only mean a bad direction functionally for the company's software going forward. I never use RStudio for research myself, but it looks like I'll stop using it in teaching.

https://finance.yahoo.com/news/palantir-posit-partner-integrate-rstudio-115900656.html

#rstudio #palantir #posit #ice

title: Research Software Engineer for Digital Behavioral Data

last_post.content:
JOB:

at the Computational Social Science Dept. at GESIS we are looking for a Research Software Engineer. The person will work on cutting-edge infrastructure for digital behavioral data.

Permanent position & detailed onboarding. Anyone with related #datascience skills can apply, independent of disciplinary background.

TVL-13, permanent postion.

Office located in Cologne, up to 60% remote work possible.

Feel free to message me with questions

https://www.hidden-professionals.de/HPv3.Jobs/gesis/stellenangebot/27897/Research-Software-Engineer-for-Digital-Behavioral-Data?lang=en-US

title: Personal Art Map with R · Implicit None

last_post.content:
What do 'Little Bunny Foo Foo ' & art maps of Boston have in common? They were both part of class today!

Most international students can't travel to be with family for the Lunar/Chinese New Year, so we talked about making beautiful maps of a place that is important to them—as well as hitting some basics of spatial data, #ggplot and image files along the way.

🗺️ 🎨 Post by @estebanmoro http://estebanmoro.org/post/2020-10-19-personal-art-map-with-r/

🐇 🎵: https://open.spotify.com/playlist/4SF1k5zV0NrPmPbUF38tdF?si=061f14269ffc468d

#Rstats #StatsEd #YearOfTheRabbit

title: What to Know About the Risks of Gas Stoves and Appliances

last_post.content:
After learning her gas stove was leaking methane, reporter
@lisalsong consulted public health experts to learn about the scope of the problem and what people can do to reduce these risks at home. @ProPublica

https://www.propublica.org/article/what-to-know-about-gas-stove-risks

So the paper that *inspired* Doug Engelbart's 1962 paper on Augmenting Human Intellect (the one that led to the personal computer in 68) was all about conceptual frameworks

And *that* paper was about multi-discliplinery collabs and also introduced "map rooms" -- a kind of room-sized physical multiplayer wiki of index cards

I dropped this loooong blog post on Friday -- it's 50% spelunking computing history, and 50% imagining future embodied computing environments

https://interconnected.org/home/2023/01/20/map_room

title: TikTok’s Secret ‘Heating’ Button Can Make Anyone Go Viral

last_post.content: One of the interesting sidenotes to the TikTok "heating" controversy is that TikTok is clearly very worried that this will get picked up by anti-China people as evidence that the Chinese state is deciding which videos will get propelled to America's youth - "Only a few people, based in the U.S., have the ability to approve content for promotion in the U.S., and that content makes up approximately .002% of videos in For You feeds." https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/01/20/tiktoks-secret-heating-button-can-make-anyone-go-viral/?sh=37a8ab856bfd

Distance cartogram based on Waldo Tobler's bidimensional regression : the unipolar accessibility from Paris to the rest of France by train in 1882 (based on data from E. Martin's document).

Da dieses Format von anderen Projekten und GLAM-Institutionen bedient wird, präsentieren auch wir den #BullingerBriefDerWoche: https://bullinger-digital.ch/letter/12821
Heute vor genau 476 Jahren schrieb Richard Hilles aus #Strasbourg an #HeinrichBullinger. Daraus lässt sich lesen, dass:
- die #Reformation noch immer im Gange ist, und z. B. in #Frankfurt versucht wird, die Messe wieder einzuführen.
- wieder #Krieg ansteht.
- König #HenryVIII von England weiterhin Leute köpfen lässt.
- auch in England gegen den Papst "gehetzt" wird.
Mehr Spannendes erfahrt ihr unter https://bullinger-digital.ch. Zudem veranstalten wir einen #Workshop: https://cl.uzh.ch/de/aboutus/events/bullinger-workshop-2023.html Darin berichten wir, wie wir den #BullingerBriefwechsel aufbereitet haben. Es sind alle Interessierten herzlich willkommen! #digitalhumanities #History

Can you vote?

You’re eligible for voting if you
- have a ticket for PyCon Italia 2023 or
- have sent a proposal for PyCon Italia 2023 or
- have attended PyCon Italia 2022 or PyCon Italia 10 or
- are a member of Python Italia

The easiest way to qualify is by getting your ticket! https://pycon.it/tickets
